cards.name: Circle of Protection: Red
cards.text: {1}: The next time a red source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage.

rulings.text: A source of damage is a permanent, a spell on the stack (including one that creates a permanent), or any object referred to by an object on the stack. A source doesn't need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice.
Can be used even when there is no damage to prevent. It prevents the next damage (if any) from the source this turn.

cards.originalText: {1}: Prevent all damage against you from one red source. If a source deals damage to you more than once in a turn, you may pay {1} each time to prevent the damage.

cards.name: Circle of Protection: White
cards.text: {1}: The next time a white source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage.

rulings.text: A source of damage is a permanent, a spell on the stack (including one that creates a permanent), or any object referred to by an object on the stack. A source doesn't need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice.
Can be used even when there is no damage to prevent. It prevents the next damage (if any) from the source this turn.

cards.originalText: {1}: Prevent all damage against you from one white source. If a source deals damage to you more than once in a turn, you may pay {1} each time to prevent the damage.

cards.name: Cold Snap
cards.text:
Cumulative upkeep {2} (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on this permanent, then sacrifice it unless you pay its upkeep cost for each age counter on it.)
At the beginning of each player's upkeep, Cold Snap deals damage to that player equal to the number of snow lands they control.
cards.flavor: Who knows from whence the winter comes?
cards.originalText:
Cumulative Upkeep: {2}
During each player's upkeep, Cold Snap deals 1 damage to that player for each snow-covered land he or she controls.

cards.name: Cooperation
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature has banding. (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding a player controls are blocking or being blocked by a creature, that player divides that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor:
"The Elves train our healers, and we keep the Orcs at bay. Most Elvish bargains aren't as fair."
—General Jarkeld, the Arctic Fox

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Target creature gains banding.

cards.name: Death Ward
cards.text: Regenerate target creature.
cards.flavor:
"Sometimes, a soul is not ready to complete its journey to the next world."
—Halvor Arenson,
Kjeldoran Priest
cards.originalText: Regenerate target creature.

cards.name: Disenchant
cards.text: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavor:
"I implore you not to forget the horrors of the past. You would have us start the Brothers' War anew!"
—Sorine Relicbane, Soldevi Heretic

rulings.text: This is not modal. If the target changes from an artifact to an enchantment or vice versa, this still destroys it.

cards.originalText: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.

cards.name: Drought
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Drought unless you pay {W}{W}.
Spells cost an additional "Sacrifice a Swamp" to cast for each black mana symbol in their mana costs.
Activated abilities cost an additional "Sacrifice a Swamp" to activate for each black mana symbol in their activation costs.

rulings.text: You have to sacrifice a Swamp for each black mana in the activation cost. If you use Pestilence with {B}{B}{B}{B}, that's 4 activations with {B} each so you sacrifice 4 Swamps.
A hybrid symbol that is both black and another type is a black mana symbol, regardless of what cost is paid for it.
Activated abilities contain a colon. They're generally written "[Cost]: [Effect]." Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.

cards.originalText: During your upkeep, pay {W}{W} or destroy Drought. Before a spell that requires {B} as part of its casting cost may be cast or an ability that requires {B} as part of its activation cost may be played, the controller of that spell or ability sacrifices a swamp for each {B} in the spell's casting cost or the ability's activation cost.

cards.name: Elvish Healer
cards.text: {T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn. If it's a green creature, prevent the next 2 damage instead.
cards.flavor:
"The Kjeldorans keep the Orcs at bay and we train their healers. Most human bargains aren't as fair."
—Laina of the Elvish Council

rulings.text: It checks the color of the creature on resolution of the ability.

cards.originalText: {T}: Prevent 1 damage to any non-green creature or any player or up to 2 damage to any green creature.

cards.name: Enduring Renewal
cards.text:
Play with your hand revealed.
If you would draw a card, reveal the top card of your library instead. If it's a creature card, put it into your graveyard. Otherwise, draw a card.
Whenever a creature is put into your graveyard from the battlefield, return it to your hand.
cards.flavor: That which lasts longest serves best.

rulings.text: Enduring Renewal only affects creature cards that are "drawn". It doesn't affect cards that are put into your hand from your library, or from anywhere else.
If the creature is only a creature due to an effect, it still goes to your hand. This includes any way to animate a card.
Token creatures cease to exist if they leave the battlefield, so this effect will not let you get them in your hand.

The last ability is now a triggered ability, not a replacement effect. That means your opponent has the opportunity to remove the card from your graveyard while the triggered ability is still on the stack.
Unless something weird happens, the card you draw as a result of the second ability will be the card you revealed.
If, after the last ability triggers, the creature card is removed from your graveyard in response, it won't be returned to your hand.

cards.originalText: Play with the cards in your hand face up on the table. If you draw a creature card from your library, discard it. Whenever a creature goes to your graveyard from play, put that creature into your hand.

cards.name: Energy Storm
cards.text:
Cumulative upkeep {1} (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on this permanent, then sacrifice it unless you pay its upkeep cost for each age counter on it.)
Prevent all damage that would be dealt by instant and sorcery spells.
Creatures with flying don't untap during their controllers' untap steps.

cards.name: Formation
cards.text:
Target creature gains banding until end of turn. (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding a player controls are blocking or being blocked by a creature, that player divides that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
Draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.
cards.flavor:
"I have been a warrior for over four hundred years, and yet each generation of Kjeldorans teaches me new tricks. There can be no better allies."
—Taaveti of Kelsinko, Elvish Hunter

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Target creature gains banding until end of turn. Draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.

cards.name: Fylgja
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Fylgja enters the battlefield with four healing counters on it.
Remove a healing counter from Fylgja: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to enchanted creature this turn.
{2}{W}: Put a healing counter on Fylgja.
cards.originalText:
When Fylgja comes into play, put four healing counters on it.
{0}: Remove a healing counter from Fylgja to prevent 1 damage to creature Fylgja enchants.
{2}{W}: Put a healing counter on Fylgja.

cards.name: General Jarkeld
cards.text: {T}: Switch the blocking creatures of two target attacking creatures. Activate this ability only during the declare blockers step.

rulings.text: Does not undo any abilities which triggered due to the declaration of blockers. A creature which is switched away still has any triggered abilities resolve on it.

The new blocker does not trigger any abilities which trigger on creatures becoming blockers, because the creatures were already blockers and the simple change of who is blocking does not trigger such abilities.

cards.originalText: {T}: Switch the blocking creatures of two target attacking creatures; all defense must remain legal. Use this ability only during combat after defense is chosen and before damage is dealt.

cards.name: Green Scarab
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't be blocked by green creatures.
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 as long as an opponent controls a green permanent.
cards.originalText: Target creature gets +2/+2 as long as any opponent controls any green cards. That creature cannot be blocked by green creatures.

cards.name: Hallowed Ground
cards.text: {W}{W}: Return target nonsnow land you control to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor:
"On this site where Kjeld's blood was spilled, let none raise a fist or deny a beggar."
—Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran Priest
cards.originalText: {W}{W}: Return target non-snow-covered land you control to owner's hand.

cards.name: Heal
cards.text:
Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
Draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.
cards.flavor:
"Sometimes even the smallest boon can save a life."
—Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran Priest

rulings.text: You draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep after Heal resolves, regardless of whether 1 damage was actually prevented.

cards.originalText: Prevent 1 damage to any creature or player. Draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.

cards.name: Hipparion
cards.text: Hipparion can't block creatures with power 3 or greater unless you pay {1}.
cards.flavor:
"Someone once said that Hipparions are to Warriors what Aesthir are to Skyknights. Don't believe it."
—General Jarkeld, the Arctic Fox
cards.originalText: Cannot be assigned to block a creature with power 3 or greater unless you pay an additional {1}.

cards.name: Justice
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Justice unless you pay {W}{W}.
Whenever a red creature or spell deals damage, Justice deals that much damage to that creature's or spell's controller.

rulings.text: If a single source does damage to multiple targets at once, Justice will add up all the damage done and deal damage to the source's controller at one time (not multiple separate damagings).
The damage done by Justice is done as a triggered ability, which is added to the stack just after the red creature or spell deals its damage.

cards.originalText: During your upkeep, pay {W}{W} or destroy Justice. Whenever a red creature or spell deals damage, Justice deals an equal amount of damage to the controller of that creature or spell. If another spell or effect reduces the amount of damage a red creature or spell deals, it does not reduce the amount of damage dealt by Justice.

cards.name: Kelsinko Ranger
cards.text: {1}{W}: Target green creature gains first strike until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Rangers not trained by the Elves just aren't the same."
—Lucilde Fiksdotter, Leader of the Order of the White Shield
cards.originalText: {1}{W}: Target green creature gains first strike until end of turn.

cards.name: Kjeldoran Elite Guard
cards.text: {T}: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn. When that creature leaves the battlefield this turn, sacrifice Kjeldoran Elite Guard. Activate this ability only during combat.
cards.flavor: The winged helms of the Guard are put on for pageants—but taken off for war.
cards.originalText: {T}: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn. If that creature leaves play this turn, bury Kjeldoran Elite Guard. Use this ability only when attack or defense is announced.

cards.name: Kjeldoran Guard
cards.text: {T}: Target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn. When that creature leaves the battlefield this turn, sacrifice Kjeldoran Guard. Activate this ability only during combat and only if defending player controls no snow lands.
cards.originalText: {T}: Target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn. If that creature leaves play this turn, bury Kjeldoran Guard. Use this ability only when attack or defense is announced and only if defending player controls no snow-covered lands.

cards.name: Kjeldoran Knight
cards.text:
Banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
{1}{W}: Kjeldoran Knight gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
{W}{W}: Kjeldoran Knight gets +0/+2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Those who do not ride the wind on Aesthir still command loyalty and respect."
—Arna Kennerüd, Skyknight

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText:
Banding
{1}{W}: +1/+0 until end of turn
{W}{W}: +0/+2 until end of turn

cards.name: Kjeldoran Phalanx
cards.text: First strike; banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor:
"There's nothing I like better than watching a street full of soldiers kicking down the doors of the guilty and the impure."
—Avram Garrisson, Leader of the Knights of Stromgald

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Banding, first strike

cards.name: Kjeldoran Royal Guard
cards.text: {T}: All combat damage that would be dealt to you by unblocked creatures this turn is dealt to Kjeldoran Royal Guard instead.
cards.flavor:
"Honorable in battle,
generous in death."
—Motto of the Kjeldoran Royal Guard

rulings.text: If you activate the ability but Kjeldoran Royal Guard leaves the battlefield before combat damage is dealt, the combat damage from unblocked creatures won't be redirected. It will be dealt to you as normal.

cards.originalText: {T}: Redirect to Kjeldoran Royal Guard all damage dealt to you from unblocked creatures this turn.

cards.name: Kjeldoran Skycaptain
cards.text: Flying; first strike; banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor:
"If we do our duty and uphold our honor, Kjeldor shall stand for a thousand years."
—Arna Kennerüd, Skyknight

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Banding, flying, first strike

cards.name: Kjeldoran Skyknight
cards.text: Flying; first strike; banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor:
"My Aesthir is my most trusted ally. We fight as one and live as one, and we will die as one."
—Arna Kennerüd, Skyknight

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Banding, flying, first strike

cards.name: Kjeldoran Warrior
cards.text: Banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor:
"Give me a thousand such Warriors and I could change the world."
—Avram Garrisson, Leader of the Knights of Stromgald

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Banding

cards.name: Lightning Blow
cards.text:
Target creature gains first strike until end of turn.
Draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.
cards.flavor:
"If you do it right, they'll never know what hit them."
—General Jarkeld, the Arctic Fox

rulings.text: You may target any creature, not just one that doesn't have first strike. If the targeted creature already has first strike as Lightning Blow resolves, Lightning Blow won't affect it (since multiple instances of first strike are redundant), but you'll still draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.

If the targeted creature doesn't have first strike, granting it first strike after combat damage has been dealt in the first combat damage step won't prevent it from dealing combat damage. It will still assign and deal its combat damage in the second combat damage step.

cards.originalText: Target creature gains first strike until end of turn. Draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.

cards.name: Lost Order of Jarkeld
cards.text:
As Lost Order of Jarkeld enters the battlefield, choose an opponent.
Lost Order of Jarkeld's power and toughness are each equal to 1 plus the number of creatures the chosen player controls.
cards.flavor:
"Let us remember brave Jarkeld and his troops, who perished in the Adarkar Wastes so long ago."
—Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran Priest
cards.originalText: Lost Order of Jarkeld has power and toughness each equal to 1 plus the number of creatures target opponent controls.

cards.name: Mercenaries
cards.text: {3}: The next time Mercenaries would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage. Any player may activate this ability.
cards.flavor:
"Blasted amateurs! Doesn't the queen think we can fight well enough on our own?"
—Avram Garrisson, Leader of the Knights of Stromgald
cards.originalText: Whenever Mercenaries damages a player, that player may pay {3} to prevent that damage.

cards.name: Order of the Sacred Torch
cards.text: {T}, Pay 1 life: Counter target black spell.
cards.originalText: {T}: Pay 1 life to destroy target black spell. Effects that prevent or redirect damage cannot be used to counter this loss of life. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Order of the White Shield
cards.text:
Protection from black
{W}: Order of the White Shield gains first strike until end of turn.
{W}{W}: Order of the White Shield gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Shall we turn away a worthy soul because his parents were peasants? I think not."
—Lucilde Fiksdotter, Leader of the Order of the White Shield
cards.originalText:
Protection from black
{W}: First strike until end of turn
{W}{W}: +1/+0 until end of turn

cards.name: Prismatic Ward
cards.text:
Enchant creature
As Prismatic Ward enters the battlefield, choose a color.
Prevent all damage that would be dealt to enchanted creature by sources of the chosen color.
cards.flavor: "These, of all spells, must have common components I can isolate and use." —Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran Priest
cards.originalText: When Prismatic Ward comes into play, choose a color; all damage dealt to target creature by sources of that color is reduced to 0.

cards.name: Rally
cards.text: Blocking creatures get +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Stand your ground, troops! This shall be our finest hour!"
—General Jarkeld, the Arctic Fox, last words
cards.originalText: All blocking creatures get +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Red Scarab
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't be blocked by red creatures.
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 as long as an opponent controls a red permanent.
cards.originalText: Target creature gets +2/+2 as long as any opponent controls any red cards. That creature cannot be blocked by red creatures.

cards.name: Sacred Boon
cards.text: Prevent the next 3 damage that would be dealt to target creature this turn. At the beginning of the next end step, put a +0/+1 counter on that creature for each 1 damage prevented this way.
cards.flavor:
"Divine gifts are granted to those who are worthy."
—Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran Priest
cards.originalText: Prevent up to 3 damage to target creature. At end of turn, put a +0/+1 counter on that creature for each 1 damage prevented by Sacred Boon.

cards.name: Seraph
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever a creature dealt damage by Seraph this turn dies, put that card onto the battlefield under your control at the beginning of the next end step. Sacrifice the creature when you lose control of Seraph.

rulings.text: You do not get the creature back if the creature is not still in the graveyard at the end of the turn.

If Seraph isn't on the battlefield at the time the other creature is put into a graveyard, the ability won't trigger. However, the ability does trigger if Seraph and the other creature are put into the graveyard at the same time.
If the other creature is a token, it will cease to exist after being exiled. It won't be returned to the battlefield.

If the other creature ceases to be a creature card after it leaves the battlefield (it's an animated Mishra's Factory, for example), it will be returned to the battlefield by this ability and you will have to sacrifice it when you lose control of Seraph.

Once the ability triggers, you'll return the card to the battlefield under your control at the end of the turn even if you no longer control Seraph at that time. In fact, if Seraph leaves the battlefield before the card is returned to the battlefield, you'll never have to sacrifice it as a result of this ability. If Seraph remains on the battlefield but changes controllers before the card is returned, you'll still get the returned card. However, in that scenario, you'll still have to sacrifice it if you later regain control Seraph and then lose control of it once more.

cards.originalText:
Flying
At the end of a turn in which any creature is damaged by Seraph and put into the graveyard, put that creature directly into play under your control as though it were just summoned. If you lose control of Seraph or if Seraph leaves play, bury the creature.

cards.name: Shield Bearer
cards.text: Banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor:
"You have almost completed your four years, my son. Soon you shall be a Skyknight."
—Arna Kennerüd, Skyknight

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Banding

cards.name: Snow Hound
cards.text: {1}, {T}: Return Snow Hound and target green or blue creature you control to their owner's hand.
cards.flavor:
"If you're starving, eat your horses, your dead, or yourself—but never eat your dog."
—General Jarkeld, the Arctic Fox
cards.originalText: {1},{T}: Return Snow Hound to owner's hand and target blue or green creature you control to owner's hand.

cards.name: Swords to Plowshares
cards.text: Exile target creature. Its controller gains life equal to its power.
cards.flavor:
"The so-called Barbarians will not respect us for our military might—they will respect us for our honor."
—Lucilde Fiksdotter, Leader of the Order of the White Shield

rulings.text: The amount of life gained is equal to the power of the targeted creature as it last existed on the battlefield.
If the creature's power is negative, its controller doesn't lose or gain life.

cards.originalText: Remove target creature from the game. That creature's controller gains life equal to its power.

cards.name: Warning
cards.text: Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt by target attacking creature this turn.
cards.flavor:
"The folk of the Karplusan Mountains are impossible to ambush."
—Lovisa Coldeyes,
Balduvian Chieftain
cards.originalText: Target attacking creature deals no damage in combat this turn.

cards.name: White Scarab
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't be blocked by white creatures.
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 as long as an opponent controls a white permanent.
cards.originalText: Target creature gets +2/+2 as long as any opponent controls any white cards. That creature cannot be blocked by white creatures.

cards.name: Altar of Bone
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, sacrifice a creature.
Search your library for a creature card, reveal that card, and put it into your hand. Then shuffle your library.

rulings.text: Because the "search" requires you to find a card with certain characteristics, you don't have to find the card if you don't want to.
You must sacrifice exactly one creature to cast this spell; you cannot cast it without sacrificing a creature, and you cannot sacrifice additional creatures.
Players can only respond once this spell has been cast and all its costs have been paid. No one can try to destroy the creature you sacrificed to prevent you from casting this spell.

cards.originalText: Sacrifice a creature to look through your library for a creature card; put that card into your hand after showing it to all other players. Reshuffle your library afterwards.

cards.name: Centaur Archer
cards.text: {T}: Centaur Archer deals 1 damage to target creature with flying.
cards.flavor:
"Centaurs will kill our Aesthir if they can; they've always been enemies. Destroy the horse-people on sight."
—Arna Kennerüd, Skyknight
cards.originalText: {T}: Centaur Archer deals 1 damage to target creature with flying.

cards.name: Chromatic Armor
cards.text:
Enchant creature
As Chromatic Armor enters the battlefield, choose a color.
Chromatic Armor enters the battlefield with a sleight counter on it.
Prevent all damage that would be dealt to enchanted creature by sources of the last chosen color.
{X}: Put a sleight counter on Chromatic Armor and choose a color. X is the number of sleight counters on Chromatic Armor.
cards.originalText:
When Chromatic Armor comes into play, put a sleight counter on it and choose a color. Any damage dealt to target creature by a source of that color is reduced to 0.
{X}: Put a sleight counter on Chromatic Armor and change the color that it protects against. X is equal to the number of sleight counters on Chromatic Armor.

cards.name: Diabolic Vision
cards.text: Look at the top five cards of your library. Put one of them into your hand and the rest on top of your library in any order.
cards.flavor:
"I have seen the true path. I will not warm myself by the fire—I will become the flame."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer
cards.originalText: Look at the top five cards of your library and put one of them into your hand. Put the remaining four on top of your library in any order.

cards.name: Earthlink
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Earthlink unless you pay {2}.
Whenever a creature dies, that creature's controller sacrifices a land.
cards.originalText:
During your upkeep, pay {2} or bury Earthlink.
Whenever a creature is put into the graveyard from play, that creature's controller sacrifices a land. Ignore this effect if that player controls no lands.

cards.name: Elemental Augury
cards.text: {3}: Look at the top three cards of target player's library, then put them back in any order.
cards.flavor:
"It is the changing of perception that is important."
—Gerda Äagesdotter,
Archmage of the Unseen
cards.originalText: {3}: Look at the top three cards of target player's library. Put them on the top of that player's library in any order.

cards.name: Essence Vortex
cards.text: Destroy target creature unless its controller pays life equal to its toughness. A creature destroyed this way can't be regenerated.
cards.flavor: Masters who sacrifice for servants will receive the gift of loyalty.
cards.originalText: Bury target creature. That creature's controller may counter this spell by paying the creature's toughness in life. Effects that prevent or redirect damage cannot be used to counter this loss of life.

cards.name: Fiery Justice
cards.text: Fiery Justice deals 5 damage divided as you choose among any number of targets. Target opponent gains 5 life.
cards.flavor: "The fire of justice burns like nothing else." —Lovisa Coldeyes, Balduvian Chieftain

rulings.text: You choose how many targets Fiery Justice has and how the damage is divided as you cast it. Each target for its damage-dealing effect must receive at least 1 damage.

If some (but not all) of the targets become illegal, the original division of damage still applies, but no damage is dealt to illegal targets. If all targets become illegal, including the target opponent for the life-gaining effect, Fiery Justice doesn't resolve. If each target for the damage-dealing effect becomes illegal while the target for the life-gaining effect remains legal, that player gains 5 life even though no damage is dealt.

The target opponent for the life-gaining effect may also be a target for the damage-dealing effect. If this happens and the damage brings that player's life total to 0 or less, the life-gaining effect will raise their life total above 0 again before the player would lose the game.

cards.originalText: Fiery Justice deals 5 damage divided any way you choose among any number of target creatures and/or players. Target opponent gains 5 life.

cards.name: Fire Covenant
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, pay X life.
Fire Covenant deals X damage divided as you choose among any number of target creatures.

rulings.text: If X is 0, the number of targets must also be 0. If X is greater than 0, the number of targets must be at least 1 and at most X. You must distribute at least 1 damage to each target.
You divide the damage as you cast the spell. You can't redistribute the damage if any of the target creatures becomes illegal before the spell resolves.

cards.originalText: Fire Covenant deals X damage, divided any way you choose among any number of target creatures, where X is equal to the amount of life you pay. Effects that prevent or redirect damage cannot be used to counter this loss of life.

cards.name: Flooded Woodlands
cards.text: Green creatures can't attack unless their controller sacrifices a land for each green creature they control that's attacking. (This cost is paid as attackers are declared.)
cards.flavor: Freyalise's tears bring life and renewal, though they also bring trouble.
cards.originalText: No green creature can attack unless its controller sacrifices a land whenever that creature attacks.

cards.name: Fumarole
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, pay 3 life.
Destroy target creature and target land.
cards.flavor:
"Too many of us have died in the explosions that wrack these hills."
—Klazina Jansdotter, Leader of the Order of the Sacred Torch

rulings.text: Fumarole can't be cast unless you can target both a creature and a land. If there's a permanent on the battlefield that's both a creature and a land, it can be both targets.

cards.originalText: Pay 3 life to destroy target creature and target land. Effects that prevent or redirect damage cannot be used to counter this loss of life.

cards.name: Ghostly Flame
cards.text: Black and/or red permanents and spells are colorless sources of damage.
cards.flavor:
"Walk slowly when in the nether world, and seek that which calls."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer

rulings.text: It does not change the color of the source, so that things that trigger on a red spell doing damage will still trigger. The damage itself thinks it came from a colorless source, however.

Does not make red and black spells and permanents colorless. They still have color. A red spell can't target a creature with Protection from Red due to this. The spells just act like colorless sources when dealing damage.
If the source has more than one color but at least one is red or black, then the damage is colorless and all the other colors are forgotten.

The effect is continuous and applies whenever something looks at the damage. If this card leaves the battlefield, damage from red and black spells will appear as its normal color. In other words, the color was not removed from the damage, the color just could not be determined while this card is in effect.

cards.originalText: Both black and red permanents and spells are considered colorless sources of damage.

cards.name: Giant Trap Door Spider
cards.text: {1}{R}{G}, {T}: Exile Giant Trap Door Spider and target creature without flying that's attacking you.
cards.flavor:
"So large and so quiet—a combination best avoided."
—Disa the Restless, journal entry

rulings.text: If Giant Trap Door Spider leaves the battlefield before its ability resolves, the ability will still resolve as normal. The targeted creature will be exiled.
If the targeted creature leaves the battlefield (or otherwise becomes an illegal target) before the ability resolves, the ability won't resolve. Giant Trap Door Spider will remain on the battlefield.

cards.originalText: {1}{R}{G},{T}: Remove from the game target creature, which doesn't have flying and is attacking you, and Giant Trap Door Spider.

cards.name: Glaciers
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Glaciers unless you pay {W}{U}.
All Mountains are Plains.
cards.flavor:
"Even the highest mountain can be ground to dust."
—Lucilde Fiksdotter, Leader of the Order of the White Shield
cards.originalText: During your upkeep, pay {W}{U} or destroy Glaciers. All mountains become plains.

cards.name: Hymn of Rebirth
cards.text: Put target creature card from a graveyard onto the battlefield under your control.
cards.flavor:
"There will come soft rains, and spring shall be amongst us, a welcome friend."
—Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran Priest
cards.originalText: Take target creature from any graveyard and put it directly into play under your control as though it were just summoned.

cards.name: Kjeldoran Frostbeast
cards.text: At end of combat, destroy all creatures blocking or blocked by Kjeldoran Frostbeast.
cards.flavor:
"Two of my Warriors found that the creature was dangerous not only in combat, but also in simple proximity."
—Disa the Restless, journal entry

rulings.text: Kjeldoran Frostbeast's ability triggers only if it's still on the battlefield when the end of combat step begins (after the combat damage step). For example, if it blocks a 7/7 creature and is destroyed, its ability won't trigger at all. The 7/7 will remain on the battlefield.

Its ability will destroy all creatures it's currently blocking or blocked by, not necessarily the creatures it had blocked or become blocked by during that combat phase. For example, if Kjeldoran Frostbeast is dealt lethal combat damage and regenerates, it's removed from combat. Its ability will trigger at end of combat, but since it's no longer blocking or blocked by any creatures, the ability won't do anything.

cards.originalText: At end of combat, destroy all creatures blocking or blocked by Kjeldoran Frostbeast.

cards.name: Merieke Ri Berit
cards.text:
Merieke Ri Berit doesn't untap during your untap step.
{T}: Gain control of target creature for as long as you control Merieke Ri Berit. When Merieke Ri Berit leaves the battlefield or becomes untapped, destroy that creature. It can't be regenerated.

rulings.text: If Merieke becomes untapped, its "destroy" ability will trigger, but you won't lose control of the creature you took before it's destroyed.

If another player takes control of Merieke, you will immediately lose control of the creature you took, but Merieke's "destroy" ability won't trigger. The affected creature will go back under the control of the appropriate player.

If Merieke leaves the battlefield, you will immediately lose control of the creature you took and Merieke's "destroy" ability will trigger. The affected creature will go back under the control of the appropriate player, then it will be destroyed.

cards.originalText:
Does not untap during your untap phase.
{T}: Gain control of target creature. Lose control of that creature if you lose control of Merieke Ri Berit. If Merieke Ri Berit leaves play or becomes untapped, bury the creature.

cards.name: Monsoon
cards.text: At the beginning of each player's end step, tap all untapped Islands that player controls and Monsoon deals X damage to the player, where X is the number of Islands tapped this way.
cards.flavor:
"No one in her right mind would venture off the coast of Kjeldor during this season."
—Disa the Restless, journal entry
cards.originalText: Whenever any island is untapped at the end of its controller's turn, tap it; Monsoon deals 1 damage to that player.

cards.name: Mountain Titan
cards.text: {1}{R}{R}: Until end of turn, whenever you cast a black spell, put a +1/+1 counter on Mountain Titan.
cards.flavor:
"The Titans claimed to draw strength from the rocks, but I suspect them of some darker allegiance."
—Disa the Restless, journal entry
cards.originalText: {1}{R}{R}: For the rest of the turn, put a +1/+1 counter on Mountain Titan whenever you successfully cast a black spell.

cards.name: Reclamation
cards.text: Black creatures can't attack unless their controller sacrifices a land for each black creature they control that's attacking. (This cost is paid as attackers are declared.)
cards.flavor:
"We shall oppose Lim-Dûl and his forces by any means necessary, even if the very earth be torn asunder."
—Arna Kennerüd, Skyknight
cards.originalText: No black creature can attack unless its controller sacrifices a land whenever that creature attacks.

cards.name: Skeleton Ship
cards.text:
When you control no Islands, sacrifice Skeleton Ship.
{T}: Put a -1/-1 counter on target creature.
cards.flavor:
"The sea gives up her dead as easily as the soil."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer
cards.originalText:
If at any time you control no islands, bury Skeleton Ship.
{T}: Put a -1/-1 counter on target creature.

cards.name: Spectral Shield
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +0/+2 and can't be the target of spells.
cards.flavor:
"What can be a stronger shield than concealment? Have you ever defeated an enemy you didn't know existed?"
—Gerda Äagesdotter,
Archmage of the Unseen

rulings.text: The enchanted creature can still be the target of abilities.

cards.originalText: Target creature gets +0/+2. That creature cannot be the target of further spells.

cards.name: Storm Spirit
cards.text:
Flying
{T}: Storm Spirit deals 2 damage to target creature.
cards.flavor:
"Come to us, with your lightning. Come to us, with your thunder. Serve us with your strength, and smite our foes with your power."
—Steinar Icefist, Balduvian Shaman
cards.originalText:
Flying
{T}: Storm Spirit deals 2 damage to target creature.

cards.name: Stormbind
cards.text: {2}, Discard a card at random: Stormbind deals 2 damage to any target.
cards.flavor:
"Once, our people could call down the storm itself to do our bidding."
—Lovisa Coldeyes,
Balduvian Chieftain

rulings.text: Since the discard is a cost, it can't be used with Library of Leng.

cards.originalText: {2}: Discard a card at random from your hand to have Stormbind deal 2 damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Wings of Aesthir
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +1/+0 and has flying and first strike.
cards.flavor:
"For those of courage, even the sky holds no limit."
—Arnjlot Olasson, Sky Mage
cards.originalText: Target creature gains flying and first strike and gets +1/+0.

cards.name: Snow-Covered Swamp

rulings.text: "Snow" has no particular meaning or rules associated with it.
Since this is a basic land, you may have any number of it in a Constructed deck in any format in which the _Masters Edition II_ set, the _Coldsnap_ set, or the _Ice Age_ set is legal.
In Limited events, you can't add basic snow lands to your deck from outside your card pool. You may add only lands named Plains, Island, Swamp, Mountain, and Forest, as normal.
Effects that target nonbasic lands can't target basic snow lands.

cards.originalText: {T}: Add {B} to your mana pool.

cards.name: Glacial Chasm
cards.text:
Cumulative upkeep—Pay 2 life. (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on this permanent, then sacrifice it unless you pay its upkeep cost for each age counter on it.)
When Glacial Chasm enters the battlefield, sacrifice a land.
Creatures you control can't attack.
Prevent all damage that would be dealt to you.

rulings.text: When Glacial Chasm's enters-the-battlefield ability resolves, if you don't control any other lands, you must sacrifice Glacial Chasm itself.

cards.originalText:
Cumulative Upkeep: 2 life
When Glacial Chasm comes into play, sacrifice a land. You cannot attack. All damage dealt to you is reduced to 0.

cards.name: Halls of Mist
cards.text:
Cumulative upkeep {1} (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on this permanent, then sacrifice it unless you pay its upkeep cost for each age counter on it.)
Creatures that attacked during their controller's last turn can't attack.
cards.originalText:
Cumulative Upkeep: {1}
No creature can attack if it attacked during its controller's last turn.

cards.name: Ice Floe
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Ice Floe during your untap step.
{T}: Tap target creature without flying that's attacking you. It doesn't untap during its controller's untap step for as long as Ice Floe remains tapped.

rulings.text: You may target a tapped creature with Ice Floe's activated ability.
The targeted creature is not removed from combat. Its attack will continue as normal.

If the ability resolves, then the creature gains flying later, Ice Floe's effect will not end. (The ability checks whether the creature has flying only at the time you activate it and the time it resolves.)

If the affected creature is untapped by some other spell or ability, Ice Floe's effect will not end. If you keep Ice Floe tapped, and that creature becomes tapped again, Ice Floe will continue to prevent it from being untapped during its controller's untap step.
Ice Floe doesn't track the creature's controller. If the affected creature changes controllers, Ice Floe will prevent it from being untapped during its new controller's untap step.

If Ice Floe untaps or leaves the battlefield, its effect will end. This has no immediate visible affect on the creature. (It doesn't untap immediately, for example.) The creature will just untap as normal during its controller's next untap step.

cards.originalText:
You may choose not to untap Ice Floe during your untap phase.
{T}: Tap target creature without flying that is attacking you. As long as Ice Floe remains tapped, that creature does not untap during its controller's untap phase.

{T}: Add {G} to your mana pool. Karplusan Forest deals 1 damage to you.

Land Cap doesn't untap during your untap step if it has a depletion counter on it.
At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a depletion counter from Land Cap.
{T}: Add {W} or {U}. Put a depletion counter on Land Cap.

{T}: Add {W} to your mana pool. Put a depletion counter on Land Cap.
{T}: Add {U} to your mana pool. Put a depletion counter on Land Cap.
